prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: For our purposes, the most significant implied contractual duty is the obligation of every employee to serve his or her employer in good faith. The duty of good faith or fidelity is well established in Canadian case law,[1] and basically requires that every employee strive to act in the employer's best interest. The most obvious requirement is a strict prohibition on actively competing with the employer during the course of the employment relationship.[2]

See, for example, Martin v. Brown (1910), 14 W.L.R. 237 (K.B.); Bee Chemical Co. v. Plastic Paint and Finish Specialties Ltd. (1978), 41 C.P.R. (2d) 175 (Ont. H.C.J.), affd 47 C.P.R. (2d) 133 (Ont. C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 47 C.P.R. (2d) 133n, 30 N.R. 356n; Alnor Services Ltd. v. Sawyer (1990), 31 C.C.E.L. 34 (B.C.S.C).

DCR Strategies Inc. v. Vector Card Services LLC, 2011 ONSC 5473, 2011 CarswellOnt 11057 (Ont. S.C.J.); Teledyne Dalsa Inc. v. Li, 2014 CarswellOnt 741, 2014 ONSC 323 (Ont. S.C.J. [Commercial List]); A Big Mobile Sign Co. v. Marshall, 2014 CarswellOnt 15, 2014 ONSC 16.
